quoteFirst: It didn’t, though. For two solid hours we groped blindly through belts of forest, across open spaces, and up and down wooded ravines, until somewhere
quoteLast: , when we reached a very large and terribly steep ravine, thickly clothed with trees, creepers, and dense undergrowth. We could hear the rushing noise of a considerable volume of water at the bottom, and in the darkness it sounded very, very far down.
title: An ivory trader in North Kenia
author: Arkell-Hardwick, A. (Alfred), 1878-1912

quoteFirst: _Apropos_ of snakes,--a naval officer had rather an amusing adventure with one at Tower Hill. He had come ashore, from a gunboat lying in the harbour, to dine at mess; and, as is usually the case, had suddenly discovered, after the third or fourth rubber,
quoteLast: , that he could not get off to his ship that night, and must trespass upon somebody’s kindness for a bed. He was assisted to a room, and the lights were being put out in the mess when we heard a series of wild shouts up stairs, and then a noise as of some heavy body thumping and banging down the steps.
title: The Land of Fetish
author: Ellis, A. B. (Alfred Burdon), 1852-1894

quoteFirst: I recollect once staying a night with some friends on Mount Macedon, where the sitting-room boasted a really huge open fireplace, in which burnt an immense log, part of the trunk of a tree, banked up with smaller pieces.  This monster burnt steadily all day till
quoteLast: , by which time the middle of it had become a glowing mass of crimson, that finally broke, with a soft crash, a flare of sparks, and thick fall of silver-grey ash.  It is a sound one grows after a time to listen for and love, this breaking of the burnt-through logs.
title: On the Wallaby Through Victoria
author: Mordaunt, Elinor, 1877?-1942

quoteLast: , and went to bed without making a light. In the morning I arose, and just as soon as I got out of bed, I fell upon the floor. My wife was alarmed and screamed.
title:
Fragments of Experience
Sixth Book of the Faith-Promoting Series. Designed for the Instruction and Encouragement of Young Latter-day Saints
author: Various

quoteFirst: The high tide at midnight sent wave after wave through the upper framework of the weakened structure. What actually happened then will never be known. Probably
quoteLast: the central support snapped off completely, leaving the topheavy 30-ton lantern tower held only by the outside piling. Then just before 1 a.m. on April 17, 1851, the great Minots Ledge Lighthouse finally slid over toward the sea. One by one the eight iron pilings broke until only three remained.
title:
Historically Famous Lighthouses
CG-232
author: United States. Coast Guard

quoteFirst: "On the evening of Wednesday, October 24th, 1860, having retired to bed about nine o'clock, I had slept, I conclude, about two hours, making it then
quoteLast: I was awoke from my sleep by a hand touching my forehead, and the well-known voice of Mrs B---- pronouncing my name, E----. I started up and sat in bed, rubbed my eyes, and then saw Mrs B----.
title: Occultism and common-sense
author: Willson, Beckles, 1869-1942; Barrett, William, Sir, 1844-1925 [Author of introduction, etc.]

quoteLast: , Major von Rheinbaben came to take leave of me. I handed to him the following letter to Herr von Jagow.
title: Fighting France

quoteLast: I waded the river half a mile above town and made a swift run to notify the armed guards doing duty at the old government barracks.
title: A cowboy detective

quoteFirst: It was now June, and the moon was rising too early. A later rising
quoteLast: , while leaving us obscured in getting out of the town, would enable us to negotiate the hills and rocky detours we proposed to make, as quickly as possible. So we decided to wait.
title:
The Secrets of a Kuttite
An Authentic Story of Kut, Adventures in Captivity and Stamboul Intrigue

quoteLast: Loud thuds on the floor above me, and a heavy thud against the door dividing my room (No. 1) from the dressing-room beyond (No. 2). I went out and listened at the servants' staircase. They were talking, but not moving about. [I learnt on inquiry that they were all in bed by 10.30.--A.G.F.
title:

Including a Journal Kept During the Tenancy of Colonel Lemesurier Taylor
